title: Concrete Calculator
description: Calculate how much concrete you need for slabs, footings, columns, and more. Get bag counts and pre-mixed delivery estimates with built-in waste factors.

meta.title: Free Concrete Calculator - Yards, Bags & Volume [2026]
meta.description: Calculate concrete needed for slabs, footings, columns & stairs. Get cubic yards, bag counts (40/60/80 lb), and delivery estimates. Free tool.
meta.keywords: concrete calculator, concrete yard calculator, concrete bag calculator, how much concrete do i need, cubic yard calculator, slab calculator, footing calculator, concrete estimator

results.title: Concrete Needed
results.smallProject: For projects under 1 cubic yard, buying bags from a hardware store is usually more economical. Consider 80 lb bags for best value.
results.largeProject: For projects over 1 cubic yard, ordering pre-mixed concrete delivery is typically more cost-effective and ensures consistent quality.

disclaimer.text: This calculator provides estimates for planning purposes. Actual concrete requirements may vary based on surface conditions, forms, and waste. Always order 5-10% extra material.
disclaimer.note: Consult with a concrete supplier for large projects. Factors like reinforcement, finishing, and local building codes may affect your requirements.

seo.whatIsContent: Calculating concrete requirements is essential for any construction project. Whether you're pouring a patio, setting fence posts, or building a foundation, knowing exactly how much concrete you need prevents costly over-ordering or project-delaying shortages. Concrete is measured in cubic yards (in the US) or cubic meters (metric), and our calculator converts your dimensions into the exact volume needed, including a waste factor for spills, uneven ground, and over-pours.
seo.formula1Desc: For patios, driveways, sidewalks, and floor slabs. Convert thickness from inches to feet before calculating.
seo.formula2Desc: For round columns, fence posts, and sonotubes. Multiply by quantity for multiple columns.
seo.formula3Desc: For foundation footings and retaining walls. All measurements in the same units.
seo.type1Desc: Yields approximately 0.30 cubic feet. Best for small repairs and post holes. Easier to handle but requires more bags.
seo.type2Desc: Yields approximately 0.45 cubic feet. Good balance between weight and coverage. Popular for medium projects.
seo.type3Desc: Yields approximately 0.60 cubic feet. Most economical per cubic foot. Best for larger DIY projects.
seo.type4Desc: Ready-mix concrete delivered by truck. Sold by the cubic yard. Most efficient for projects over 1 cubic yard.
seo.howToStep1: Select your project type (slab, footing, column, stairs, or custom volume)
seo.howToStep2: Choose your preferred unit system (imperial or metric)
seo.howToStep3: Enter the dimensions of your project
seo.howToStep4: Adjust the waste factor if needed (10% is standard)
seo.howToStep5: View your results showing cubic yards, bag counts, and delivery recommendations
seo.tip1: Always order 5-10% extra concrete to account for waste, spillage, and uneven surfaces
seo.tip2: For slabs, standard thickness is 4 inches; use 6 inches for driveways and heavy loads
seo.tip3: Concrete cures best between 50-85°F (10-30°C); avoid pouring in extreme temperatures
seo.tip4: Have all forms, reinforcement, and tools ready before mixing or delivery arrives
seo.tip5: For bags, mix only what you can pour in 10-15 minutes to prevent premature setting
seo.faq1Question: How many bags of concrete do I need?
seo.faq1Answer: The number of bags depends on your project volume and bag size. An 80 lb bag yields about 0.60 cubic feet. For a 4-inch thick, 10×10 ft slab (33.33 cu ft), you'd need approximately 56 bags of 80 lb concrete. Our calculator does this math automatically and shows options for 40, 60, and 80 lb bags.
seo.faq2Question: How much concrete is in a yard?
seo.faq2Answer: One cubic yard equals 27 cubic feet and covers approximately 80 square feet at 4 inches thick, or 65 square feet at 5 inches thick. This is enough for a typical 8×10 ft patio. Most concrete trucks deliver in full or partial yard increments.
seo.faq3Question: How thick should a concrete slab be?
seo.faq3Answer: Standard thickness depends on use: 4 inches for patios and walkways, 5-6 inches for driveways, and 6-8 inches for heavy vehicle traffic. Always check local building codes, as minimum thickness requirements vary by region and application.
seo.faq4Question: Should I add more concrete for waste?
seo.faq4Answer: Yes, always add 5-10% for waste. Our calculator includes an adjustable waste factor (default 10%). Waste accounts for uneven ground, spillage, over-pours, and concrete left in the mixer. For complex shapes or rough terrain, consider adding up to 15%.
seo.faq5Question: When should I order ready-mix vs bags?
seo.faq5Answer: For projects under 0.5 cubic yards, bags are usually more practical. For 0.5-1 cubic yard, either option works depending on access and timeline. For over 1 cubic yard, ready-mix delivery is more economical and ensures consistent quality. Ready-mix also saves significant labor time.
seo.faq6Question: How long does concrete take to cure?
seo.faq6Answer: Concrete reaches about 70% strength in 7 days and full strength in 28 days. You can walk on it after 24-48 hours and drive on it after 7 days. Keep it moist during the first week by spraying with water or covering with plastic to prevent cracking.
seo.faq7Question: Do I need reinforcement in concrete?
seo.faq7Answer: For most DIY projects like patios and walkways, wire mesh or fiber reinforcement is sufficient. Driveways benefit from wire mesh or rebar. Structural applications like foundations require rebar per engineering specifications. Reinforcement helps prevent cracking from ground movement and temperature changes.
seo.faq8Question: What PSI concrete should I use?
seo.faq8Answer: Standard concrete mix is 3,000-4,000 PSI, suitable for most residential projects including patios, walkways, and footings. Use 4,000-5,000 PSI for driveways and areas with vehicle traffic. High-strength applications may require 5,000+ PSI. Bagged mixes typically come in 3,500-5,000 PSI options.
